results.title: Michael Palin's Hemingway adventure
results.creator_credit: David F. Turnbull, Martha Wailes and BBC
results.brief_description: In the tradition of previous work of Palin’s that includes “Around the World in Eighty Days” and “Pole to Pole”, this is a beautifully filmed and cleverly narrated documentary which traces Palin’s journey in the footsteps of American writer Ernest Hemingway. In his attempts to experience Hemingway’s adventures things don’t always work quite as planned, but the result is always humourous and insightful both on the contradictory literary giant and the impact of the diversity of sights Palin visits. His tour includes such attractions as the fireworks of Valencia, the streets of Paris, the outback of Uganda and the snows of Kilimanjaro that feature in Hemingway’s work. Palin’s mastery of narrational comedy and Nigel Meakin’s skilled camerawork makes this a highly energetic travelogue.

results.title: Michael Hall: sculptor
results.creator_credit: Sue Marx and Little Red Filmhouse
results.brief_description: Sculptor Michael Hall talks about his work and the creative process. Indicates that his work can be approached on a number of different levels and that he draws on personal experience for his work.

results.title: Mice and men
results.brief_description: Examines differing social patterns of mice and insects, and indicates similarities between mice and men. Discusses instinctive behaviour, relationships, social dominance and how man’s intervention can alter this dominance. Looks also at aggression and the prevention of unlimited aggression. Spoken by Brian Inglis and Bob Holness. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: MGM: when the lion roars
results.creator_credit: Frank Martin, Joni Levin, Point Blank Productions and Turner Pictures
results.brief_description: A fascinating tribute to the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studio and its films, stars and perhaps most importantly, the two perfectionists who were the starmakers and overseers of this movie kingdom - the patriarchal Louis B. Mayer and the “Boy Wonder”, Irving G. Thalberg, whose foresight and talent shaped the evolution of motion pictures. This programme takes an amazing look at the dream factory which in its heyday produced approximately fifty-two motion pictures each year, created some of the biggest stars in Hollywood history and stayed true to the company’s motto of ‘art for art’s sake’. This definitive history of MGM unfolds through film clips, interviews, behind-the-scenes footage and inside information never before made available. The programme is broken into three segments: part one - “The Lion’s roar”. Part two - “The Lion reigns supreme”. Part three - “The Lion in winter”. Hosted by the ever suave Patrick Stewart.

results.title: MGM Cartoon Christmas
results.brief_description: 35 minutes of MGM christmas cartoons including: ALIAS ST. NICK; a cynical mouse doesn’t believe in Santa Clause: THE PUPS’ CHRISTMAS; two puppies have some fun playing with Christmas gifts: THE PEACHY COBBLER; a poor shoemaker feeds his last piece of bread to some birds who pay him back by fixing all the shoes in his shop: PEACE ON EARTH; the 1939 Oscar nominated parable directed by Hugh Harman features tiny animals recounting how men have annihilated themselves with war.

results.title: Mexico: the golden egg
results.creator_credit: Frank Jacoby, Robert Allison and United Nations Television
results.brief_description: Illustrates how a Mexican community develops new health and self-respect through techniques in food and poultry productions, gained by cooperation among the Mexican government, UNESCO, FAO, and the Tarascan Indian villagers of the Patzcuaro area to the west of Mexico City.

results.title: Mexico in the 70's: heritage and progress
results.creator_credit: Frank Gardony and BFA Educational Media
results.brief_description: The blending of centuries of tradition with modern technology is seen through the eyes of three Mexicans - a farmer, a butcher and an architect. Mexicans take greayt pride in their Indian culture and in the contributions of their past civilizations. Traditional customs are not ignored but used as a basis for growth and progress.

results.title: Mexican maize
results.creator_credit: Roger Sandall, Dorothy Cinquemani and American Museum of Natural History
results.brief_description: A view of life in the high mountains of Guerrero, showing the dependence of Mexican Indian peasants on maize. Shows the men as they burn over the field, plant, and cultivate maize, the women and children as they work and play at preparing tortillos, and the fiesta at the end of the corn ploughing season.

results.title: Metropolis
results.creator_credit: Taro Rin, Iwao Yamaki, Masao Maruyama, Mad House and Toho Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description: Combining traditional cell animation with state of the art computer animation, Metropolis wildly re-imagines Fritz Lang’s 1927 silent film of the same name. Based on the 1945 Manga comic by Osamu Tezuka (Astroboy, Kimba the white lion), Metropolis conjures a dystopic, unspecified future where a sprawling city becomes a battleground between the elite ruling class and the subterranean dwelling robots, created to run the capital’s mammoth industry. A young boy named Kenichi and his detective uncle arrive into this troubled city to investigate an underground organization whose main agenda is to annihilate androids. As the cities citizens move closer to total anarchy, Kenici befriends an advanced female robot who was created for ominous dictator Duke Red in the image of his dead daughter. Director Taro Rin and writer Katsuhiro Otomo (Akira) combine Lang’s classic tale (apparently Tezuka’s original inspiration for the comic was a poster he saw for Lang’s Metropolis, subsequently writing the story without ever seeing the film) with more contemporary works such as Ridley Scott’s Blade Runner, creating a visually spectacular hybrid of science fiction, film noir and Manga comics.
